case_name: Gurbinder Singh and Balbinder Singh v. Lal Singh and Pratap Singh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 431 of 1963 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated May 21, 1958 of the Punjab High Court in Civil Regular Second Appeal No. 263-P of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 431 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated May 21, 1958 of the Punjab High Court in Civil Regular Second Appeal No. 263-P of 1952.

facts.text: Mst. Raj Kaur was in possession of 851 kanals 18 marlas of land situate in village Dhaipai in the former State of Faridkot.

anchor.surface_text: In order to appreciate the contentions it is necessary to set out the relevant facts which are no longer in dispute. Mst. Raj Kaur was in possession of 851 kanals 18 marlas of land situate in village Dhaipai in the former State of Faridkot.

facts.text: Out of the land, 481 kanals 7 marlas was in possession of Mst. Raj Kaur as occupancy tenant, landlord being the Raja of Faridkot.

anchor.surface_text: Out of this land 481 kanals 7 marlas was in her possession as occupancy tenant, the landlord being the Raja of Faridkot while the remaining land was held by Smt. Raj Kaur as Adna Malik, the Aala malik again being the said Raja of Faridkot.

facts.text: The remaining land was held by Smt. Raj Kaur as Adna Malik, Aala Malik being the Raja of Faridkot.

anchor.surface_text: while the remaining land was held by Smt. Raj Kaur as Adna Malik, the Aala malik again being the said Raja of Faridkot. In Samvat 1953 (A.D.1896) Smt. Raj Kaur who had two daughters Prem Kaur and Mahan Kaur, adopted the formers son Bakshi Singh

facts.text: In Samvat 1953 (A.D. 1896), Smt. Raj Kaur adopted the former's son Bakshi Singh and put him in possession of the whole of the land.

anchor.surface_text: In Samvat 1953 (A.D.1896) Smt. Raj Kaur who had two daughters Prem Kaur and Mahan Kaur, adopted the formers son Bakshi Singh and put him in possession of the whole of the land.

facts.text: Bakshi Singh transferred part of the land to Pratap Singh, second son of Mahan Kaur, respondent No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: Bakshi Singh transferred part of the land to Pratap Singh, second son of Mahan Kaur, who is respondent No. 2 in the appeal. Mahan Kaur had one more son Lal Singh and he is respondent No. 1 in this appeal.

facts.text: In the year 1915, the Raja of Faridkot filed a suit against Bakshi Singh and Raj Kaur for declaration that the adoption of Bakshi Singh was invalid.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1915 the Raja of Faridkot filed a suit against Bakshi Singh and Raj Kaur in the court of Sub-Judge, Faridkot for a declaration that the adoption of Bakshi Singh was invalid.

facts.text: The suit by Raja was decreed on February 9, 1916.

anchor.surface_text: This suit was decreed on February 9, 1916. Raj Kaur died on August 14, 1930.

facts.text: Raj Kaur died on August 14, 1930.

anchor.surface_text: Raj Kaur died on August 14, 1930. On February 19, 1934 the Raja filed two suits against Bakshi Singh and Pratap Singh for possession of the aforementioned lands,

facts.text: On February 19, 1934, the Raja filed two suits against Bakshi Singh and Pratap Singh for possession of the lands.

anchor.surface_text: On February 19, 1934 the Raja filed two suits against Bakshi Singh and Pratap Singh for possession of the aforementioned lands, one pertaining to the land of which Raj Kaur was occupancy tenant and the other for that of the land of which she was Adna malik.

facts.text: The two suits by Raja were decreed on March 12, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: These suits were decreed on March 12, 1938 and in execution of the decrees obtained in these suits the Raja took possession of the entire land in October 1938.

facts.text: Raja took possession of the entire land in October 1938.

anchor.surface_text: and in execution of the decrees obtained in these suits the Raja took possession of the entire land in October 1938. On April 7, 1948 he sold the entire land along with some other land to one Kehar Singh

facts.text: On April 7, 1948, Raja sold the entire land along with some other land to Kehar Singh for Rs. 84,357-5-0.

anchor.surface_text: On April 7, 1948 he sold the entire land along with some other land to one Kehar Singh for Rs. 84,357-5-0. Thereupon Gurbinder Singh and Balbinder Singh. who are the appellants before us,

facts.text: Gurbinder Singh and Balbinder Singh filed a suit for pre-emption against Kehar Singh and obtained a decree, got possession on June 22, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon Gurbinder Singh and Balbinder Singh. who are the appellants before us, filed a suit for pre-emption of the land against Kehar Singh and obtained a decree in their favour. In execution of that decree they got possession of the land on June 22, 1950.

facts.text: On October 20, 1948, Mst. Prem Kaur instituted a suit for possession of the entire land against Kehar Singh and Raja of Faridkot.

anchor.surface_text: On October 20, 1948 Mst. Prem Kaur instituted a suit for possession of the entire land on the ground that she was the legal heir of Raj Kaur against Kehar Singh and the Raja of Faridkot.

facts.text: On February 17, 1950, Lal Singh filed a suit for possession of the entire land against Raja and Kehar Singh, joined Prem Kaur and Pratap Singh as defendants; Pratap later transposed as plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: On February 17, 1950, Lal Singh, respondent No. 1, filed a suit for possession of the entire land against the Raja of Faridkot and Kehar Singh. To that suit he joined Prem Kaur and Pratap Singh as defendants. Later, however, Pratap Singh was transposed as a plaintiff.

facts.text: Both suits of Prem Kaur and respondents were consolidated and tried together; Prem Kaur's dismissed, respondents' decreed to half share.

anchor.surface_text: Both the suits were consolidated and were tried together. The suit of Prem Kaur was dismissed by the trial court but that of the respondents was decreed to the extent of half share in the property.

facts.text: Appeals by Prem Kaur and appellants to District Court dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Prem Kaur and the appellants preferred appeals before the District Court but that court dismissed both the appeals.

facts.text: Second appeals by appellants and Prem Kaur to High Court dismissed, along with respondents' cross-objections.

anchor.surface_text: A second appeal was taken by the appellants as well as by Prem Kaur to the High Court and cross-objections were preferred by the respondents. The High Court dismissed these appeals as well as the cross-objections.

facts.text: Mahan Kaur died on July 13, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: Mahan Kaur had in fact died on July 13, 1938, i.e. before the Raja obtained possession.

facts.text: The relevant facts are no longer in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: In order to appreciate the contentions it is necessary to set out the relevant facts which are no longer in dispute.

facts.text: Raj Kaur had two daughters: Prem Kaur and Mahan Kaur.

anchor.surface_text: Smt. Raj Kaur who had two daughters Prem Kaur and Mahan Kaur, adopted the formers son Bakshi Singh

facts.text: Pratap Singh was in possession of part of the property by transfer from Bakshi Singh.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that Pratap Singh was in possession of part of the property--which particular part we do not know--by reason of a transfer thereof in his favour by Bakshi Singh.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds the suit is within time under Article 144 of Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the respondents suit is within time and has been rightly decreed by the courts below.

issues.text: whether the suit for possession instituted by the respondents Lal Singh and Pratap Singh is within time

anchor.surface_text: The only question for consideration in this appeal by certificate from the High Court of Punjab is whether the suit for possession instituted by the respondents Lal Singh and Pratap Singh is within time.

issues.text: whether art. 142 is attracted to the suit

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Tarachand Brijmohanlal for the appellants also relied on art. 144 in the alternative. In order that art. 142 is attracted the plaintiff must initially have been in possession of the property and should have been dispossessed by the defendant or someone through whom the defendants claim or alternatively the plaintiff should have discontinued possession.

issues.text: whether under art. 144 the suit is barred by time

anchor.surface_text: It is in these circumstances that we have to consider whether under art. 144 the suit is barred by time. The starting point of limitation set out in col. 3 of art. 144 is as follows When the possession of the defendant becomes adverse to the plaintiff.

Mahan Kaur had in fact died on July 13, 1938, i.e. before the Raja obtained possession. Therefore, it is more accurate to say that the possession of the Raja became adverse to Prem Kaur and to the respondents Lal Singh and Pratap Singh as from October, 1938.

This is a suit to which art. 144 is attracted and the burden is on the defendant to establish that he was in adverse possession for 12 years before the date of suit and for companyputation of this period he can avail of the adverse possession of any person or persons through whom he claims --but number the adverse possession of independent trespassers.

arguments.claim: Agency Co. v. Short supports no tacking successive independent trespassers; possession resets on abandonment

anchor.surface_text: Further the doctrine of independent trespassers will companye in only when the second man trespasses upon the possession of the first or the first man abandons possession. Where it applies the principle laid down in Agency Cos 1  case-would apply and preclude the tacking of possession of successive trespassers.

arguments.claim: Suit within time under art. 144 as adverse possession starts October 1938 and total <12 years

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the respondents suit is within time and has been rightly decreed by the companyrts below.

holdings.text: Article 142 of the Limitation Act is not attracted to the suit because the plaintiffs-respondents were never in possession of the property as heirs of Raj Kaur.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that Pratap Singh was in possession of part of the property--which particular part we do not know--by reason of a transfer thereof in his favour by Bakshi Singh. In the present suit both Lal Singh and Pratap Singh assert their claim to property by succession in accordance with the rules contained in the dastur ul amal whereas the possession of Pratap Singh for some time was under a different title altogether. So far as the present suit is concerned it must, therefore, be said that the plaintiffs--respondents were never in possession as heirs of Raj Kaur and consequently art. 142 would not be attracted to their suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiffs claim by succession; prior possession of Pratap Singh under different title from transfer by Bakshi Singh, not as heir.

holdings.text: The suit is governed by Article 144 of the Limitation Act; limitation runs from when the possession of the defendant becomes adverse to the plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: It is in these circumstances that we have to consider whether under art. 144 the suit is barred by time. The starting point of limitation set out in col. 3 of art. 144 is as follows When the possession of the defendant becomes adverse to the plaintiff.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 141 conceded inapplicable; Art. 142 rejected; Art. 144 applies as plaintiff out of possession.

holdings.text: Though obtained under court decree, Raja's possession was that of a trespasser against Raj Kaur's heirs and became adverse to them from October 1938.

anchor.surface_text: Though the Raja obtained possession under a decree of the court he was in the eye of law nothing but a trespasser in so far as the heirs of Raj Kaur, her daughters Prem Kaur and Mahan Kaur were concerned. Mahan Kaur had in fact died on July 13, 1938, i.e. before the Raja obtained possession. Therefore, it is more accurate to say that the possession of the Raja became adverse to Prem Kaur and to the respondents Lal Singh and Pratap Singh as from October, 1938.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decree invalid against true owners (daughters entitled under dastur-ul-amal); adverse from dispossession date.

holdings.text: Adverse possession of Raja, Kehar Singh, and appellants totals less than 12 years from October 1938 to suit date.

anchor.surface_text: Kehar Singh who was a transferee from the Raja stood in the Rajas position and got the benefit of the Rajas adverse possession. Similarly the appellants who had preempted these lands under the decree obtained against Kehar Singh got advantage not only of the Rajas adverse possession but also of Kehar Singhs. The sum total of the adverse possession of these three persons at the date of the respondents suit would, however, be less than 12 years

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tacking allowed only through privity (transferees); period from Raja's entry to suit <12 years.

holdings.text: Adverse possession of independent trespassers (Bakshi Singh and Pratap Singh) cannot be tacked onto that of the Raja and his transferees.

anchor.surface_text: The Raja in his suit against Bakshi Singh challenged the right of Bakshi Singh and Pratap Singh to possession on the ground that they were trespassers. As it has turned out, the possession of the Raja, though obtained under the decree of a civil court, was in itself a trespass on the rights of the persons who were in law entitled to possession of property. Thus this is a case of one trespasser trespassing against another trespasser. There is no connection between the two and, therefore, in law their possession cannot be tacked on to one another.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Raja trespassed against prior trespassers (Bakshi/Pratap); no privity or connection between successive independent trespassers.

holdings.text: Under the definition of 'defendant' in s.2 of Limitation Act, tacking requires jural relationship; none exists between independent trespassers.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from that what we are concerned with is the language used by the legislature in the third column of art. The starting point of limitation there stated is the date when the possession of the defendant becomes adverse to the plaintiff. The word defendant is defined in s. 2(4) of the Limitation Act thus defendant includes any person from or through whom a defendant derives his liability to be sued. No doubt, this is an inclusive definition but the gist of it is the existence of a jural relationship between different persons. There can be no jural relationship between two independent trespassers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inclusive definition implies privity ('from or through whom'); independent trespassers lack such relationship.

holdings.text: The respondents' suit for possession is within time under Article 144 and rightly decreed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.144 governs; adverse possession starts Oct 1938; no tacking prior trespassers; total period <12 years.

anchor.surface_text: In support of the contention reliance is placed by learned counsel on the decision in Ramayya v. Kotamma 1 . In order to appreciate what was decided in that case a brief resume of the facts of that case is necessary. Mallabattudu, the last male holder of the properties to which the suit related, died in the year 1889 leaving two daughters Ramamma and Govindamma. The former died in 1914. The latter surrendered her estate to her two sons. The plaintiff who was a transferee from the sons of Govindamma instituted a suit for recovery of possession of Mallabattudus property against Punnayya, the son of Ramamma to whom Mallabattudu had made an oral gift of his properties two years before his death.

precedents.cited_proposition: Tacking adverse possession of successive trespassers or persons under invalid title for limitation purposes under Art. 142
precedents.cited_holding: Time runs against the last owner and exclusion by different trespassers does not stop limitation if continuity in exclusion.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court following the decision of Mookerjee J. in Mohendra Nath v. Shamsunnessa 3 held that time begins to run against the last full owner if he himself was dispossessed and the operation of the law of limitation would not be arrested by the fact that on his death he was succeeded by his widow, daughter or mother, as the cause of action cannot be prolonged by the mere transfer of title.

precedents.cited_proposition: Limitation runs against last full owner and not arrested by succession upon death

anchor.surface_text: it was argued on the authority of Agency Co. v. Short 1 that in cases of successive trespassers limitation ceases to run against the lawful owner of the land after an intruder has relinquished his possession that on the death of Punnayya it must be taken that there was an interruption in the possession and that there was an interval between Punnayyas death and Subbarayudus taking possession in his own right however minute the interval may be and that except in the case of succession or revolution all other cases would fall within the principle enunciated in Agency Cos case 1

precedents.cited_proposition: Successive independent trespassers cannot tack possession; abandonment resets possession to owner
precedents.cited_holding: The possession of the intruder, ineffectual for the purpose of transferring title, ceases upon its abandonment to be effectual for any purpose. It does not leave behind it any cloud on the title of the rightful owner.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges did not accept the contention but relying upon the decision in Willis v. Earl Howe 2 and a passage in Dart on Vendors and Purchasers, Vol. 17th ed. p. 474 held that the suit was barred by time.

precedents.cited_proposition: Continuity of possession where presumptive heir continues possession

precedents.citation: Rajagopala Naidu v. Ramasubramania Ayyar 1 [AIR 1935 Mad. 449]

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by Varadachariar J., in Rajagopala Naidu v. Ramasubramania Ayyar 1 . Further the doctrine of independent trespassers will come in only when the second man trespasses upon the possession of the first or the first man abandons possession. Where it applies the principle laid down in Agency Cos 1 case-would apply and preclude the tacking of possession of successive trespassers.

precedents.cited_proposition: Doctrine of independent trespassers applies only when second trespasses on first's possession or first abandons; otherwise no tacking

anchor.surface_text: Further the doctrine of independent trespassers will come in only when the second man trespasses upon the possession of the first or the first man abandons possession. Where it applies the principle laid down in Agency Cos 1 case-would apply and preclude the tacking of possession of successive trespassers. The following observations of Lord Macnaghten in that case are pertinent and run thus They are of opinion that if a person enters upon the land of another and holds possession for a time, and then, without having acquired title under the statute, abandons possession, the rightful owner, on the abandonment, is in the same position in all respects as he was before the intrusion took place.

precedents.cited_proposition: Principle against tacking possession of successive independent trespassers
precedents.cited_holding: If a person enters upon the land of another and holds possession for a time, and then, without having acquired title under the statute, abandons possession, the rightful owner... is in the same position...

anchor.surface_text: It is true that Pratap Singh was in possession of part of the property--which particular part we do not know--by reason of a transfer thereof in his favour by Bakshi Singh. In the present suit both Lal Singh and Pratap Singh assert their claim to property by succession in accordance with the rules contained in the dastur ul amal whereas the possession of Pratap Singh for some time was under a different title altogether. So far as the present suit is concerned it must, therefore, be said that the plaintiffs--respondents were never in possession as heirs of Raj Kaur and consequently art. 142 would not be attracted to their suit.
In our opinion, therefore, the respondents suit is within time and has been rightly decreed by the courts below.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 that suit governed by Article 144 addresses issue i3 of whether barred by time under art. 144.

anchor.surface_text: It is in these circumstances that we have to consider whether under art. 144 the suit is barred by time. The starting point of limitation set out in col. 3 of art. 144 is as follows When the possession of the defendant becomes adverse to the plaintiff.
In our opinion, therefore, the respondents suit is within time and has been rightly decreed by the courts below.

edges.explanation: h3 establishes adverse possession starts October 1938, supporting h4 that total adverse possession of Raja, Kehar Singh, and appellants is less than 12 years from then to suit.

anchor.surface_text: Though the Raja obtained possession under a decree of the court he was in the eye of law nothing but a trespasser in so far as the heirs of Raj Kaur, her daughters Prem Kaur and Mahan Kaur were concerned. Mahan Kaur had in fact died on July 13, 1938, i.e. before the Raja obtained possession. Therefore, it is more accurate to say that the possession of the Raja became adverse to Prem Kaur and to the respondents Lal Singh and Pratap Singh as from October, 1938.
In our opinion, therefore, the respondents suit is within time and has been rightly decreed by the courts below.

edges.explanation: Holding h4 that adverse possession totals less than 12 years addresses issue i3 of whether suit barred by time under art. 144.

anchor.surface_text: Kehar Singh who was a transferee from the Raja stood in the Rajas position and got the benefit of the Rajas adverse possession. Similarly the appellants who had preempted these lands under the decree obtained against Kehar Singh got advantage not only of the Rajas adverse possession but also of Kehar Singhs. The sum total of the adverse possession of these three persons at the date of the respondents suit would, however, be less than 12 years
In our opinion, therefore, the respondents suit is within time and has been rightly decreed by the courts below.

anchor.surface_text: The Raja in his suit against Bakshi Singh challenged the right of Bakshi Singh and Pratap Singh to possession on the ground that they were trespassers. As it has turned out, the possession of the Raja, though obtained under the decree of a civil court, was in itself a trespass on the rights of the persons who were in law entitled to possession of property. Thus this is a case of one trespasser trespassing against another trespasser. There is no connection between the two and, therefore, in law their possession cannot be tacked on to one another.
In our opinion, therefore, the respondents suit is within time and has been rightly decreed by the courts below.

edges.explanation: Holding h6 addresses issue i5 by concluding no jural relationship under s.2 defendant definition.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from that what we are concerned with is the language used by the legislature in the third column of art. The starting point of limitation there stated is the date when the possession of the defendant becomes adverse to the plaintiff. The word defendant is defined in s. 2(4) of the Limitation Act thus defendant includes any person from or through whom a defendant derives his liability to be sued. No doubt, this is an inclusive definition but the gist of it is the existence of a jural relationship between different persons. There can be no jural relationship between two independent trespassers.
In our opinion, therefore, the respondents suit is within time and has been rightly decreed by the courts below.
